data.name: THIS n' THAT
data.description:
Note: This kata has nothing to do with JavaScript's keyword `this`.
>```
THIS
```
`pronoun / ˈt͟his , t͟həs /`

>A one-word response following another user's statement or question in an online forum or chat service, e.g., Slack; used to express intense agreement with said user's message--often preceded or replaced by a caret (`^`).
>```
For example:
Thing1: I could really go for some pancakes right now.
Thing2: ^
        THIS
```
>Other definitions: (https://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=This)

### --------------------------------
## _**THIS**_

Write a function `THIS` that returns a string `n` levels of the following pattern, henceforth known as THIS:

>THIS(1);
```
console.log(THIS(1)); // should appear as:
^
THIS
```
THIS(2);
```
console.log(THIS(2)); // should appear as:
 ^
/ \
THIS THIS
```
THIS(10);
```
console.log(THIS(10)); // should appear as:
         ^
        / \
       /   \
      /     \
     /       \
    /         \
   /           \
  /             \
 /               \
/                 \
THIS THIS THIS THIS THIS THIS THIS THIS THIS THIS
```

But to make it faster to express your enthusiasm for someone's message, calling `THIS` with no arguments should also return one level of THIS:
```javascript
THIS() === THIS(1); // true```

Further, sometimes you may be so excited to express THIS that you may type something like `THIS('!@#$%^&*');`, in which case your function should also return one level of THIS.
```javascript
THIS('!@#$%^&*'); === THIS(1); // true
```

In fact, when `n` is anything other than a positive integer it should always return one level of THIS, *unless* JavaScript would otherwise throw an error:
```javascript
THIS('') === THIS(1); // true
THIS(0) === THIS(1); // true
THIS(null) === THIS(1); // true
THIS(-1) === THIS(1); // true
...
// for most implementations this throws a RangeError as its result
// would exceed the maximum string length (not tested for):
THIS(Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER); // RangeError
...
```
### --------------------------------
## _**Throw an Error**_
However, your implementation should explicitly throw an `Error` when `n` is a positive number with any non-zero digits after the decimal separator; negative numbers are OK:
```javascript
THIS(4.8); // Error | to avoid partial levels (e.g., THI)
THIS(-6.022) === THIS(1); // true
```
### --------------------------------
## _**Flip THIS for THAT**_

`THIS` also takes an optional second argument `THAT` that when passed any _**truthy**_ value, instead of pointing upwards like the THIS pattern, the return value should be flipped and point downwards, replacing `THIS` with `THAT` and `^` with `v`:

>Note that `true` could also be replaced by any _**truthy**_ value; e.g., `1`.

>THIS(1, true);
```
console.log(THIS(1, true)); // should appear as:
THAT
v
```
THIS(2, true);
```
console.log(THIS(2, true)); // should appear as:
THAT THAT
\ /
 v
```
THIS(10, true);
```
console.log(THIS(10, true)); // should appear as:
THAT THAT THAT THAT THAT THAT THAT THAT THAT THAT
\                 /
 \               /
  \             /
   \           /
    \         /
     \       /
      \     /
       \   /
        \ /
         v
```

### --------------------------------
## _**Looping Constraints**_

Finally, as an additional constraint, your solution must contain no more than one `for * loop, while loop, forEach, map, reduce, reduceRight, find, findIndex, filter, some, or every`. Your code will be checked and an error will be thrown if it contains more than one of these.

```
Me: Have fun with the kata!
You: ^
     THIS
You: LOLOL
```
